Training Time Minimization for Federated Edge Learning with Optimized Gradient Quantization and Bandwidth Allocation

Peixi Liu  Jiamo Jiang  Guangxu Zhu  Lei Cheng  Wei Jiang  Wu Luo  Ying Du  Zhiqin Wang Peixi Liu is with State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communication Systems and Networks, School of Electronics, Peking University, Beijing, China, and Shenzhen Research Institute of Big Data, Shenzhen, China (e-mail: liupeixi@pku.edu.cn).Jiamo Jiang, Ying Du and Zhiqin Wang are with China Academy of Information and Communications Technology (e-mail: jiangjiamo, duying1, zhiqin.wang@caict.ac.cn).Guangxu Zhu is with Shenzhen Research Institute of Big Data, Shenzhen, China (e-mail: gxzhu@sribd.cn).Lei Cheng is with College of Information Science and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China (e-mail: lei_cheng@zju.edu.cn)Wei Jiang and Wu Luo are with State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communication Systems and Networks, School of Electronics, Peking University, Beijing, China (e-mail: jiangwei, luow@pku.edu.cn).
Abstract

Training a machine learning model with federated edge learning (FEEL) is typically time-consuming due to the constrained computation power of edge devices and limited wireless resources in edge networks. In this paper, the training time minimization problem is investigated in a quantized FEEL system, where the heterogeneous edge devices send quantized gradients to the edge server via orthogonal channels. In particular, a stochastic quantization scheme is adopted for compression of uploaded gradients, which can reduce the burden of per-round communication but may come at the cost of increasing number of communication rounds. The training time is modeled by taking into account the communication time, computation time and the number of communication rounds. Based on the proposed training time model, the intrinsic trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency is characterized. Specifically, we analyze the convergence behavior of the quantized FEEL in terms of the optimality gap. Further, a joint data-and-model-driven fitting method is proposed to obtain the exact optimality gap, based on which the closed-form expressions for the number of communication rounds and the total training time are obtained. Constrained by total bandwidth, the training time minimization problem is formulated as a joint quantization level and bandwidth allocation optimization problem. To this end, an algorithm based on alternating optimization is proposed, which alternatively solves the subproblem of quantization optimization via successive convex approximation and the subproblem of bandwidth allocation via bisection search. With different learning tasks and models, the validation of our analysis and the near-optimal performance of the proposed optimization algorithm are demonstrated by the experimental results.

Index Terms:
Federated edge learning, quantization optimization, bandwith allocation, training time minimization

I Introduction

The evolution of wireless networks from 1G to 5G-Advanced has witnessed a paradigm shift from connecting people targeting human-type communications towards connecting intelligence targeting machine-type communications to attain the vision of artificial intelligence of things (AIoT). This has driven the rapid development of an emerging area called edge intelligence, sitting at the intersection of the two disciplines, namely artificial intelligence (AI) and wireless communications [1, 2]. In edge intelligence, AI technologies are pushed towards the network edge so that the edge servers can quickly access real-time data generated by edge devices for fast training and real-time inference [3]. A promising framework for distributed edge learning, called federated edge learning (FEEL), has recently been pushed into the spotlight, which distributes the task of model training to edge devices and keeps the data locally at the edge devices so as to avoid data uploading and thus preserve user-privacy [4, 5, 6]. Specifically, a typical training process of FEEL involves multiple rounds of wireless communication between the edge server and devices. In a particular round, the edge server firstly broadcasts the global model under training to the edge devices for local stochastic gradient decent (SGD) execution using local data, and then the edge devices upload their local models/gradients to the edge server for aggregation and global model updating. After the convergence criterion is met, such as attaining a desired level of accuracy or reaching a pre-defined value of the loss, the entire training process will be completed, and then on-device models can be tweaked for the edge device’s personalization.

In edge networks, the computation resource of the edge devices are constrained, and the wireless resource of the network, e.g., frequency bandwidth, is also limited, so training a AI model by FEEL is usually a time-consuming and expensive task that can take anywhere from hours to weeks to complete [7]. Hence, training time111This is also called wall-clock time in some literature [8, 9]. In this work, we use “total training time”, “training time”, and “wall-clock time” interchangeably. minimization of AI models is one of the critical concerns in FEEL. The whole training process of FEEL typically consists of multiple communication rounds, and each lasts for a period of time consisting of computation time and communication time, which we called per-round latency. To reduce the total training time, we should not only bring down the number of communication rounds, i.e., speed up the convergence rate of the learning algorithm, but also shorten the per-round latency. Communication-efficient transmission achieved through compression is usually included into the FEEL pipeline to alleviate the transmission burden of the edge devices, and thus reduce the per-round latency [10]. Two main lossy compression techniques, namely quantization and sparsification, as well as combination of them, have been considered in the literature [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. Specifically, in the case of quantization, the gradient vector entries are transmitted after being quantized to finite bits, instead of the full floating-point values [14, 15, 16]; sparsification reduces the communication overhead by only sending significant entries of the gradient vector [17, 18, 19]. Although the compressed transmission can decrease the per-round latency, the lossy compression will degrade the convergence speed of FEEL as well, which leads to the increase in the number of communication rounds to achieve a certain accuracy on a given task [13]. As a result, the compression level balances the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency in minimization of the total training time in FEEL. Besides, the edge devices in the edge network are usually heterogeneous such that some of edge devices with lower computation power become laggards in the synchronous model/gradient aggregation due to their longer computation time, which increases the per-round latency. It is necessary to consider the optimization of wireless resources over different edge devices to reduce the communication time of the lagging edge devices, and compensate the longer computation time [20, 21, 22]. With the goal of minimizing the total training time, we study the following question: How to balance the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency via joint quantization level and bandwidth allocation optimization in the presence of device heterogeneity.

I-A Related work

Recently, extensive efforts have been made to minimize the total training time of FEEL by resource allocation or gradient/model compression, which mainly fall into three categories in terms of their objectives:

I-A1 Minimization of the number of communication rounds

This is equivalent to accelerating the convergence speed of FEEL algorithms. In [4], the authors minimized the global loss function by optimizing communication resource, e.g., power and bandwidth, and computation resource under given per-round latency constraint, and thus the convergence speed was maximized. The works in [23] and [24] considered quantization and bandwidth optimization to accelerate the algorithm convergence speed of FEEL with device sampling in the presence of outage probability. In [25], a stochastic gradient quantization was adopted to compress the local gradient, and the quantization levels of each devices were optimized to minimize the optimality gap under multiple access channel capacity constraints. These efforts have focused on speeding up the convergence of FEEL algorithms, i.e., reducing the number of communication rounds, without considering minimizing the total training time, which is a more practical and important issue in FEEL.

I-A2 Minimization of per-round latency

The work in [20] and [21] studied the trade-off between per-round latency and energy consumption by introducing a weight factor, and these two objectives tend to form a competitive interaction. In [5], the authors analyzed the per-round latency of different multiple access schemes in FEEL, i.e., the proposed broadband analog aggregation (BAA) and the traditional OFDMA, and proved that the proposed BAA can significantly reduce the per-round latency compared to the traditional OFDMA. The resource allocation in [20], [21], and [5] were considered over each single communication round; nevertheless, FEEL is a long-term process consisting of many communication rounds that together determine the total training time.

I-A3 Minimization of total training time

The work in [22] minimized the total training time by optimizing communication and computation resource allocation; however, no compression was considered in [22]. The authors in [7] minimized the training time for a fixed communication rounds by solving a joint learning, wireless resource allocation, and device selection problem. Some of other works didn’t minimize the training time directly, but they considered to minimize the loss function in a given training time. For example, the work in [9] studied the communication trade-off balanced by compression and local update steps in fixed training time, but the communication resource allocation was not taken into consideration. The authors in [26] adopted the idea of signSGD with majority vote [27] and optimized the power allocations and CPU frequencies under the trade-off between the number of communication rounds versus the outage probability per communication round for fixed training time.

Despite the above research efforts, these prior works have overlooked the inherent trade-off in minimizing the total training time of communication-efficient FEEL between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency, which is balanced by the quantization level at the edge devices. Moreover, the communication resource allocation among different edge devices and the compression setup for minimizing the total training time of communication-efficient FEEL should be jointly considered. This thus motivates the current work.

I-B Our contribution

This paper studies a FEEL system consisting of multiple edge devices with heterogeneous computational capabilities and one edge server for coordinating the learning process. We consider quantized FEEL where a stochastic quantization scheme is adopted for updated gradients compression, which can save per-round communication cost but may at a cost of increased number of communication rounds. Thus, we make a comprehensive analysis on the total training time by taking into account the communication time, computation time and the number of communication rounds, based on which the intrinsic trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency is characterized. Then, building on the analytical results, a joint quantization and bandwidth allocation optimization problem is formulated and solved. The main contributions are elaborated as follows.

  • •

    Training time analysis in quantized FEEL: The challenge of analyzing the total training time mainly lies in estimating the required communication rounds for model convergence. To tackle the challenge, we analyze the convergence behavior of quantized FEEL in terms of the optimality gap and establish the expression of the minimum number of communication rounds that achieves a given optimality gap of the loss function. However, the derived results are generally too loose to be used for further optimization. In order to yield an accurate estimate on the required number of communication rounds, we propose a joint data-and-model-driven fitting method to further refine and tighten the derived result. Thanks to the refinement, an accurate estimate of the total training time can be attained and the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency can be better characterized.

  • •

    Training time minimization via joint optimization of quantization and bandwidth: Next, building on the derived analytical results, we formulate the total training time minimization problem by jointly optimizing the quantization level and bandwidth allocation, subject to a maximum bandwidth constraint in FEEL network. The problem is non-convex, and thus challenging to solve. To tackle the challenge, we adopt the alternating optimization technique to decompose the problem into two subproblems, and each optimizes one of the two control variables with the other fixed. For the sub-problem of bandwidth allocation with fixed quantization level, it can be solved by bisection search efficiently; for the sub-problem of quantization optimization with bandwidth allocation fixed, a algorithm based on successive convex approximation is proposed.

  • •

    Performance evaluation: Finally, we conduct extensive simulations to evaluate the performance of task-oriented resource allocation for quantized FEEL by considering the logistic regression (convex loss function) on a synthetic dataset and a convolution neural network (non-convex loss function) on CIFAR-10 dataset. It is shown that the proposed joint data-and-model-driven fitting method can fit the curve of actual optimality gap well. In addition, it is shown that the optimal quantization level found by solving the formulated optimization problem matches well with the simulation result. The benefits of optimizing the bandwidth allocation in coping with the devices heterogeneity are also demonstrated.

I-C Organization and notations

Organization: The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the system model, including the FEEL procedure, the quantization scheme, and the channel models. Section III analyzes the convergence of quantized FEEL,where a joint-data-and-model driven fitting approach is proposed to attain a tight approximation of the total training time. The optimization problem for minimizing the total training time is formulated and then solved in Section IV. Section V shows the experimental results using synthetic and real dataset, followed by conclusion in Section VI.

II System model

II-A Federated learning

We consider a quantized federated edge learning (FEEL) system consisting of K𝐾K edge devices and a single edge server, as shown in Fig. 1. With the coordination of the edge server, the edge devices collaboratively train a shared model, which is represented by the parameter vector 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with d𝑑d denoting the model size. The training process is to minimize the following empirical loss function

Suppose device k𝑘k holds the training data set 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} with a uniform size of D𝐷D, i.e., |𝒟k|=Dsubscript𝒟𝑘𝐷\left|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right|=D. Fk​(𝐰)=1D​∑(𝐱i,yi)∈𝒟kf​(𝐰;𝐱i,yi)+λ​R​(𝐰),subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰1𝐷subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘𝑓𝐰subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜆𝑅𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}f(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})+\lambda R(\mathbf{w}), (1)

where f​(𝐰;𝐱i,yi)𝑓𝐰subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖f(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i}) denotes the sample-wise loss function specified by the learning task and quantifies the training loss of the model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} on the training data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and its ground-true label yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}, and R​(𝐰)𝑅𝐰R(\mathbf{w}) denotes certain strongly convex regularization function whose strength is controlled by a hyperparameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0.

In FEEL, the training process is implemented iteratively in a distributed manner using the federated stochastic gradient decent (FedSGD) algorithm as elaborated in the following. Consider a particular iteration or communication round n𝑛n, all the devices first download the current model 𝐰(n)superscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}^{(n)} from the server. Then, each device computes a local stochastic gradient, 𝐠k(n)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}, using a randomly chosen mini-batch of samples from data sets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} in a uniform manner. We denote the set of mini-batch samples used by device k𝑘k at round n𝑛n as 𝒟~k(n)subscriptsuperscript~𝒟𝑛𝑘\tilde{\mathcal{D}}^{(n)}_{k} and the size of each mini-batch as mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b}. Then we have

𝐠k(n)=1mb​∑(𝐱i,yi)∈𝒟~k(n)∇f​(𝐰(n);𝐱i,yi)+λ​∇R​(𝐰(n)).superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛1subscript𝑚𝑏subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscriptsuperscript~𝒟𝑛𝑘∇𝑓superscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜆∇𝑅superscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}=\frac{1}{m_{b}}\sum_{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\tilde{\mathcal{D}}^{(n)}_{k}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w}^{(n)};\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})+\lambda\nabla R(\mathbf{w}^{(n)}). (2)

Next, each device transmits a quantized version of its local gradient, i.e., 𝒬​(𝐠k(n))𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}), to the edge server. The quantization scheme will be elaborated in the next subsection. Upon the reception, the edge server aggregates the local gradients and updates the global model as follows:

𝐰(n+1)=𝐰(n)−ηnK​∑k=1K𝒬​(𝐠k(n)),superscript𝐰𝑛1superscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝜂𝑛𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}=\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}),

where ηnsubscript𝜂𝑛\eta_{n} denotes the learning rate at round n𝑛n. Then the updated global model will be broadcast back to all edge devices for initializing the next round training. The above procedure continues until the convergence criterion is met.

II-B Stochastic quantization

We consider a widely-used stochastic quantizer for local gradient quantization [14]. where the output of quantizer 𝒬​(𝐠)𝒬𝐠\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}) consists of three parts, i.e., the vector norm ‖𝐠‖norm𝐠\|\mathbf{g}\|, the sign of each entry sgn​(gi)sgnsubscript𝑔𝑖\mathrm{sgn}(g_{i}) with gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} denoting the i𝑖i-th entry of 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g}, and the quantization value of each entry ξi​(𝐠,q)subscript𝜉𝑖𝐠𝑞\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q). {ξi​(𝐠,q)}subscript𝜉𝑖𝐠𝑞\left\{{\xi_{i}}\left({{\mathbf{g}},q}\right)\right\} are independent random variables defined as

As proved in Lemma 3.1 from [14], the random quantizer 𝒬​(𝐠)𝒬𝐠\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}) is unbiased, i.e., 𝔼​[𝒬​(𝐠)]=𝐠𝔼delimited-[]𝒬𝐠𝐠\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g})]=\mathbf{g} for any given vector 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g}. Moreover, assuming that d≥q2𝑑superscript𝑞2d\geq q^{2}, the quantizer has a bounded variance, i.e., 𝔼​[‖𝒬​(𝐠)−𝐠‖]2≤dq​‖𝐠‖2𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]norm𝒬𝐠𝐠2𝑑𝑞superscriptnorm𝐠2\mathbb{E}[\left\|\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g})-\mathbf{g}\right\|]^{2}\leq\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q}\left\|\mathbf{g}\right\|^{2}. Note that we do not claim that this quantization scheme is optimal in terms of the communication efficiency. Rather, we adopt it as a simple and general scheme that facilitates the subsequent analysis of the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round communication latency, controlled by the quantization level.

II-C Wireless transmission model

In the quantized FEEL system, each edge device connects to the edge server via a shared wireless medium. We assume that the spectrum is divided into distinct and non-overlapping flat fading channels with different bandwidth, so that the edge devices share the spectrum through frequency division multiple access to avoid interferences with each other. In general, modern neural network models are of high dimension with d𝑑d in the order of 106∼109similar-tosuperscript106superscript10910^{6}\sim 10^{9}. Hence, it usually takes much longer than the coherence period to transmit a complete model. For example, a single LTE frame of 5 MHz bandwidth and 10 ms duration can carry only 6000 complex symbols [12]. To transmit a moderate neural network model with 106superscript10610^{6} parameters encoded by 32-bit floating-point values, it will approximately take 6 seconds, which is much longer than the frame length, i.e., 10 ms. Moreover, in some Internet of Things (IoT) networks, which are typically bandwidth and power limited [28], it takes more time to transmit a machine learning model. Hence, it is reasonable to model the wireless uplink channels as independent and identical distributed (i.i.d.) fast Rayleigh fading channel in the course of training, i.e., the channel coefficients remain constant over each coherence period and vary in an i.i.d. across different coherence periods, and the codeword or frame will span multiple coherence periods [29]. Specifically, the channel propagation coefficient between edge server and device k𝑘k is generally modeled as hk=ϕk​h¯ksubscriptℎ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscript¯ℎ𝑘h_{k}=\sqrt{\phi_{k}}\overline{h}_{k}; here, ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k} describes the large-scale propagation effects, including path loss and shadowing, and h¯ksubscript¯ℎ𝑘\overline{h}_{k} denotes small-scale fading modeled as i.i.d. CSCG random variables with zero mean and unit variance, i.e., h¯k∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscript¯ℎ𝑘𝒞𝒩01\overline{h}_{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,1). The large-scale propagation coefficient ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k} remains unchanged in a whole time frame, while the small-scale fading h¯ksubscript¯ℎ𝑘\overline{h}_{k} varies from coherence block to another in a time frame. Moreover, we assume that the channel coefficients are only known at the edge server, which can be obtained by channel estimation at the server.

In this situation, the ergodic capacity can be assigned to the fast fading channel, which can be achieved in practice by interleaving technique [29]. The ergodic capacity of device k𝑘k is given by

Rk=𝔼hk​[bk​log2⁡(1+pk​|hk|2bk​N0)],subscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝔼subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑏𝑘subscript21subscript𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝑁0R_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{h_{k}}\left[b_{k}\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{p_{k}|h_{k}|^{2}}{b_{k}N_{0}}\right)\right], (4)

where bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} denotes the frequency bandwidth allocated for device k𝑘k with ∑k=1Kbk=B0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝐵0\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}=B_{0}; pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} denotes the transmit power at device k𝑘k; N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} denotes noise power spectral density; the expectation is taken over the channel distribution.

III Training time analysis

The training time of each device for one communication round comprises computation time Tkcompsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compT_{k}^{\text{comp}} and communication time Tkcommsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commT_{k}^{\text{comm}}, as illustrated in Fig. 2. Since the server broadcasts the same global model to all the devices using the entire frequency band, the downlink delay due to global model broadcasting is ignorable compared with the uplink delay due to updates uploading from many devices to the server. Assume that the delay requirement for running one round training is Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d}, i.e., Tkcomp+Tkcomm≤Tdsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}\leq T_{d}. We define Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} as the minimum number of communication rounds when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-optimality gap is achieved, i.e., F​(𝐰(Nϵ))−F​(𝐰∗)≤ϵ𝐹superscript𝐰subscript𝑁italic-ϵ𝐹subscript𝐰∗italic-ϵF(\mathbf{w}^{(N_{\epsilon})})-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})\leq\epsilon, where 𝐰∗subscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}_{\ast} denotes the optimal model as 𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰)subscript𝐰∗subscript𝐰𝐹𝐰\mathbf{w}_{\ast}=\arg\min\limits_{\mathbf{w}}F(\mathbf{w}). The training process stops when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-optimality gap is achieved. Then, the requirement of total training time over Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} rounds is given by

T=Nϵ⋅Td.𝑇⋅subscript𝑁italic-ϵsubscript𝑇𝑑T=N_{\epsilon}\cdot T_{d}. (5)

In the following, we give the expression of per-round training time Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d}, and obtain the minimum number of communication rounds Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} by analyzing the convergence of FEEL, which paves the way for minimizing the total training time defined in (5) in next section.

III-A Computation time

Let ν𝜈\nu denote the number of processing cycles for one particular edge device to execute one batch of samples, and fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} denote the CPU frequency of device k𝑘k. Accordingly, the computation time for running one-round SGD at device k𝑘k is given by [30]

Tkcomp=νfk.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘comp𝜈subscript𝑓𝑘T_{k}^{\text{comp}}=\frac{\nu}{f_{k}}.

III-B Communication time

Let S𝑆S denote the number of bits for transmission after stochastic quantization. For quantizing any element gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} in gradient vector 𝐠∈ℝd𝐠superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{g}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} as noted from (2), we need to encode the vector norm ‖𝐠‖norm𝐠\|\mathbf{g}\|, the element-wise sign sgn​(gi)sgnsubscript𝑔𝑖\mathrm{sgn}(g_{i}), and the normalized quantization value ξi​(𝐠,q)subscript𝜉𝑖𝐠𝑞\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q) into bits. Particularly, it takes one bit to encode each of the sgn​(gi)sgnsubscript𝑔𝑖\mathrm{sgn}(g_{i}). Assuming that ξi​(𝐠,q)subscript𝜉𝑖𝐠𝑞\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q)’s have uniform distribution222In practice, ξi​(𝐠,q)subscript𝜉𝑖𝐠𝑞\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q)’s can have non-uniform probability distribution. There exit more efficient coding methods coping with such non-uniform distribution as reported in [14], which are nevertheless much more complicated for analysis and optimization. In this work, we only consider the uniform distribution and leave those complicated ones for future work. with support {0,1/q,2/q,…,1\{0,1/q,2/q,\dots,1}, it takes at least log2⁡(1+q)subscript21𝑞\log_{2}(1+q) bits to encode each ξi​(𝐠,q)subscript𝜉𝑖𝐠𝑞\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q) [31]. Since each vector containing d𝑑d entries, it takes in total (1+log2⁡q)​d1subscript2𝑞𝑑(1+\log_{2}q)d bits to encode these two parts. By contrast, the overhead in encoding the single scalar vector norm ‖𝐠‖norm𝐠\|\mathbf{g}\| is typically negligible for large models of size d𝑑d [32]. To facilitate the subsequent analysis, for large d𝑑d we approximate S𝑆S via

S=(1+log2⁡(q+1))​d.𝑆1subscript2𝑞1𝑑S=(1+\log_{2}(q+1))d. (6)

The communication delay in one round is

Tkcomm=SRk,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘comm𝑆subscript𝑅𝑘T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=\frac{S}{R_{k}}, (7)

where Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} is the ergodic capacity defined in (4).

III-C Minimum number of communication rounds

In this subsection, we derive Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} by analyzing the convergence of quantized FEEL. To this end, we make the following assumptions on the local loss functions {Fk​(𝐰)}subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\{F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\}.

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

The local loss functions {Fk​(𝐰)}subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\{F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\} are all L𝐿L-smooth: for all 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} and 𝐰jsubscript𝐰𝑗\mathbf{w}_{j}, Fk​(𝐰i)≤Fk​(𝐰j)+(𝐰i−𝐰j)T​∇Fk​(𝐰j)+L2​‖𝐰i−𝐰j‖2subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑗𝐿2superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗2F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\leq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right)^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\frac{L}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right\|^{2}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k.

Assumption 2 (Strongly convexity).

The local loss functions {Fk​(𝐰)}subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\{F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\} are all μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex: for all 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} and 𝐰jsubscript𝐰𝑗\mathbf{w}_{j}, Fk​(𝐰i)≥Fk​(𝐰j)+(𝐰i−𝐰j)+(𝐰i−𝐰j)T​∇Fk​(𝐰j)+μ2​‖𝐰i−𝐰j‖2subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑗subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑗𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗2F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\geq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right)+\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right)^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right\|^{2}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k.

Assumption 3 (First and second moments of local gradients).

The mean and variance of stochastic gradients 𝐠k(n)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)} of local loss functions Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), for all n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in[N] and ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, satisfy that

(Unbiased) 𝔼​[𝐠k(n)]=∇Fk​(𝐰(n)),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}]=\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)}),
(Bounded variance) 𝔼​[‖𝐠k(n)−∇Fk​(𝐰(n))‖2]≤δk2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}-\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}]\leq\delta_{k}^{2}.

Assumptions 1 and 2 on local loss functions are standard, and they can be satisfied by many typical learning models, such as logistic regression, linear regression, and softmax classifier. Assumption 3 is general enough to cope with both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. data distribution across edge devices, which follows the work in [33], [24], and [34]. Under Assumptions 1-3, the convergence rate of quantized FEEL is established in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Consider a quantized FEEL system with fixed quantization level q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2. The optimality gap of the loss function after N𝑁N communication rounds is upper bounded by

𝔼​[F​(𝐰(N))]−F​(𝐰∗)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑁𝐹subscript𝐰∗\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{(N)})\right]-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})
≤α​κN+2​α​κ−1​(L​‖𝐰(0)−𝐰∗‖2+2​Γμ),absent𝛼𝜅𝑁2𝛼𝜅1𝐿superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰0subscript𝐰∗22Γ𝜇\displaystyle\leq\frac{\alpha\kappa}{N+2\alpha\kappa-1}\left(L\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(0)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}\right),

where α=dq​K+1𝛼𝑑𝑞𝐾1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1, κ=Lμ𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu}, Fδ=F​(𝐰∗)−1K​∑k=1KFk∗subscript𝐹𝛿𝐹subscript𝐰∗1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘∗F_{\delta}=F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}F_{k}^{\ast} with Fk∗=min𝐰⁡Fk​(𝐰)superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘∗subscript𝐰subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}^{\ast}=\min\limits_{\mathbf{w}}F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), Γ=2​L​Fδ+1K​∑k=1Kδk2Γ2𝐿subscript𝐹𝛿1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2\Gamma=2LF_{\delta}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\delta_{k}^{2}, and 𝐰(0)superscript𝐰0\mathbf{w}^{(0)} is the initial point of the training process. The learning rate is set to be a diminishing one, i.e., ηn=2μ​(n+2​α​κ−1)subscript𝜂𝑛2𝜇𝑛2𝛼𝜅1\eta_{n}=\frac{2}{\mu(n+2\alpha\kappa-1)}.

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Remark 1 (Convergence rate).

Theorem 1 quantizes the impact of gradient quantization on the convergence rate of the FEEL, which is captured by the term α=dq​K+1𝛼𝑑𝑞𝐾1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1. An aggressive quantization scheme, e.g., with small q𝑞q, will lead to a enlarged optimality gap, and thus needs more rounds to converge. Nevertheless, the quantized FEEL can still achieve the asymptotic convergence rate of 𝒪​(1N)𝒪1𝑁\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{N}) as federated learning without quantization [33].

Remark 2 (Impact of data heterogeneity).

The term Fδsubscript𝐹𝛿F_{\delta} measures the discrepancy between the minimum global loss and the average of the minimum local losses, which can be used for quantifying the heterogeneity level of data distribution among different devices [33]. As observed, if the data distribution is i.i.d., i.e., the data at different devices is sampled from a same distribution, then Fδsubscript𝐹𝛿F_{\delta} goes to zero as the number of samples grows; otherwise, Fδsubscript𝐹𝛿F_{\delta} is a non-zero constant depending on the skewness of data distribution. Therefore, Theorem 1 also offers quantitative insights on how data heterogeneity affects the convergence of quantized FEEL.

Although we can readily establish a bound on Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} based on Theorem 1 and apply this bound for subsequent resource optimization as did in prior work, e.g., [35] and [34], such an approach has two key drawbacks. Firstly, the gap between the derived bound and its true value could be large as several relaxations are made in deriving the bound. Thus, ignoring the gap may lead to highly suboptimal solution in the subsequent resource optimization. Secondly, even we adopt the upper bound and ignore the effects of the gap, it is still difficult to get the exact value of upper bound, since it involves calculating a bunch of data-related and model-related parameters, such as μ𝜇\mu, L𝐿L, Fδsubscript𝐹𝛿F_{\delta}, 𝐰∗subscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}_{\ast}, and ΓΓ\Gamma.

To address the above issues, we propose a joint data-and-model-driven fitting approach, which uses a small amount of pre-training rounds to yield a good estimate of the optimality gap based on the bound derived in Theorem 1. To this end, we first denote the upper bound function derived in Theorem 1 as follows,

U^​(N)=α​κ​(L​‖𝐰0−𝐰∗‖2+2​Γμ)N+2​α​κ−1.^𝑈𝑁𝛼𝜅𝐿superscriptnormsubscript𝐰0subscript𝐰∗22Γ𝜇𝑁2𝛼𝜅1\hat{U}(N)=\frac{\alpha\kappa\left(L\left\|\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}\right)}{N+2\alpha\kappa-1}.

Before we derive the tight estimate of optimality gap, it is first observed that the upper bound function U^​(N)^𝑈𝑁\hat{U}(N) satisfies the following properties:

  1. 1.

    U^​(N)^𝑈𝑁\hat{U}(N) is a decreasing function of N𝑁N, and it converges to zero in a rate of 𝒪​(1N)𝒪1𝑁\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{N});

  2. 2.

    U^​(N)^𝑈𝑁\hat{U}(N) has a fractional structure, where the numerator and denominator are both linear increasing functions of α𝛼\alpha.

We assume that the ground-true optimality gap follows the same properties as its upper bound U^​(N)^𝑈𝑁\hat{U}(N). Based on the above assumption, the exact optimality gap can be well estimated by the following function:

𝔼​[F​(𝐰(N))]−F​(𝐰∗)=α​A+Dn+α​B+C≜U​(N),𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑁𝐹subscript𝐰∗𝛼𝐴𝐷𝑛𝛼𝐵𝐶≜𝑈𝑁\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{(N)})\right]-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})=\frac{\alpha A+D}{n+\alpha B+C}\triangleq U(N), (8)

where A>0𝐴0A>0, B>0𝐵0B>0, C≥0𝐶0C\geq 0, and D≥0𝐷0D\geq 0 are tuning parameters to be fitted, which are implicitly related to the parameters, such as μ𝜇\mu, L𝐿L, Fδsubscript𝐹𝛿F_{\delta}, and ΓΓ\Gamma. It can be seen that U​(N)𝑈𝑁U(N) generalizes all the functions that satisfy the two properties mentioned above.

Next, we apply a joint data-and-model-driven fitting method to fit the values of the tuning parameters as follows. Firstly, we randomly choose two quantization levels, say q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}, and run the quantized FEEL with q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}, respectively, from an initial model 𝐰0subscript𝐰0\mathbf{w}_{0}. Then we sample the value of loss at each round until the number of communication rounds reaches a pre-defined value N~~𝑁\tilde{N}. The corresponding loss values are denoted as Fi,nsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑛F_{i,n} (i∈{1,2}𝑖12i\in\{1,2\}, n∈[1,N~]𝑛1~𝑁n\in[1,\tilde{N}]) for round n𝑛n when the quantization level is qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}. According to (8), we have that

Fi,n−Z≈Xin+Yi,∀i∈{1,2},n∈[1,N~],formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑖𝑛𝑍subscript𝑋𝑖𝑛subscript𝑌𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖12𝑛1~𝑁F_{i,n}-Z\approx\frac{X_{i}}{n+Y_{i}},\;\forall i\in\{1,2\},\;n\in[1,\tilde{N}], (9)

where αi=dqi​K+1subscript𝛼𝑖𝑑subscript𝑞𝑖𝐾1\alpha_{i}=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q_{i}K}+1, Z=F​(𝐰∗)𝑍𝐹subscript𝐰∗Z=F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}), and

Xisubscript𝑋𝑖\displaystyle X_{i} =αi​A+D,absentsubscript𝛼𝑖𝐴𝐷\displaystyle=\alpha_{i}A+D, (10)
Yisubscript𝑌𝑖\displaystyle Y_{i} =αi​B+C.absentsubscript𝛼𝑖𝐵𝐶\displaystyle=\alpha_{i}B+C. (11)

Then we aim to find proper values of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}, Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i}, and Z𝑍Z to fit (9) well. The method we choose is to solve the following nonlinear regression problem:

minXi,Yi,Z​∑i=12∑n=1N~((Fi,n−Z)​(n+Yi)−Xi)2.subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖𝑍minsuperscriptsubscript𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑛𝑍𝑛subscript𝑌𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖2\underset{X_{i},Y_{i},Z}{\text{min}}\;\sum_{i=1}^{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\big{(}(F_{i,n}-Z)(n+Y_{i})-X_{i}\big{)}^{2}. (12)

For any fixed Z𝑍Z, this problem can be divided into two linear regression problems, i.e.,

minXi,Yi​∑n=1N~((Fi,n−Z)​(n+Yi)−Xi)2,subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖minsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑛𝑍𝑛subscript𝑌𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖2\underset{X_{i},Y_{i}}{\text{min}}\;\;\;\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\big{(}(F_{i,n}-Z)(n+Y_{i})-X_{i}\big{)}^{2}, (13)

and the optimal {Xi}subscript𝑋𝑖\{X_{i}\} and {Yi}subscript𝑌𝑖\{Y_{i}\} can be given by

Xi=∑n=1N~χi,n​∑n=1N~ψi,n2−∑n=1N~χi,n​ψi,n​∑n=1N~ψi,nN​∑n=1N~ψi,n2−(∑n=1N~ψi,n)2,subscript𝑋𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜒𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜒𝑖𝑛subscript𝜓𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜓𝑖𝑛𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑛2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜓𝑖𝑛2X_{i}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\chi_{i,n}\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n}^{2}-\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\chi_{i,n}\psi_{i,n}\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n}}{N\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n}^{2}-(\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n})^{2}}, (14)

and

Yi=∑n=1N~χi,n​∑n=1N~ψi,n−N​∑n=1N~χi,n​ψi,nN​∑n=1N~ψi,n2−(∑n=1N~ψi,n)2subscript𝑌𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜒𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜓𝑖𝑛𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜒𝑖𝑛subscript𝜓𝑖𝑛𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑛2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1~𝑁subscript𝜓𝑖𝑛2Y_{i}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\chi_{i,n}\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n}-N\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\chi_{i,n}\psi_{i,n}}{N\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n}^{2}-(\sum_{n=1}^{\tilde{N}}\psi_{i,n})^{2}} (15)

where χi,n=(Fi,n−Z)​nsubscript𝜒𝑖𝑛subscript𝐹𝑖𝑛𝑍𝑛\chi_{i,n}=(F_{i,n}-Z)n and ψi,n=Fi,n−Zsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑛subscript𝐹𝑖𝑛𝑍\psi_{i,n}=F_{i,n}-Z. Hence, the problem in (12) can be solved by one-dimensional search of Z𝑍Z. Since the computations in (14) and (15) only involve limited algebraic operations, the computation time for solving the problem in (12) is negligible compared with the whole training process. With {Xi}subscript𝑋𝑖\{X_{i}\} and {Yi}subscript𝑌𝑖\{Y_{i}\} at hand, A𝐴A, B𝐵B, C𝐶C, D𝐷D can be obtained from (10) and (11) as following:

A𝐴\displaystyle A =X1−X2α1−α2,absentsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2\displaystyle=\frac{X_{1}-X_{2}}{\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}},
B𝐵\displaystyle B =Y1−Y2α1−α2,absentsubscript𝑌1subscript𝑌2subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2\displaystyle=\frac{Y_{1}-Y_{2}}{\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}},
C𝐶\displaystyle C =α2​Y1−α1​Y2α2−α1,absentsubscript𝛼2subscript𝑌1subscript𝛼1subscript𝑌2subscript𝛼2subscript𝛼1\displaystyle=\frac{\alpha_{2}Y_{1}-\alpha_{1}Y_{2}}{\alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}},
D𝐷\displaystyle D =α2​X1−α1​X2α2−α1.absentsubscript𝛼2subscript𝑋1subscript𝛼1subscript𝑋2subscript𝛼2subscript𝛼1\displaystyle=\frac{\alpha_{2}X_{1}-\alpha_{1}X_{2}}{\alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}}.

Based on the estimated optimality gap in (8) with the well-fitted parameters, we can derive Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} as in the following proposition.

Proposition 1.

In the quantized FEEL system, the minimum communication rounds to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-optimality gap is given by

Nϵ=⌈(dq​K+1)​(Aϵ−B)+Dϵ−C⌉.subscript𝑁italic-ϵ𝑑𝑞𝐾1𝐴italic-ϵ𝐵𝐷italic-ϵ𝐶N_{\epsilon}=\left\lceil\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1\right)\left(\frac{A}{\epsilon}-B\right)+\frac{D}{\epsilon}-C\right\rceil. (16)
Proof.

By setting the fitted optimality gap in (8) less than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, i.e., U​(N)≤ϵ𝑈𝑁italic-ϵU(N)\leq\epsilon, and respecting the fact that the minimum communication rounds should be an integer, we obtain (16). ∎

Remark 3 (Impact of quantization level and device number).

Proposition 1 unveils the impact of quantization level and the number of participating devices on the minimum communication rounds as reflected by the term dq​K+1𝑑𝑞𝐾1\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1. On one hand, Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} decreases with increasing number of the quantization level q𝑞q. This is due to the fact that increasing the quantization levels leads to less quantization error, which speeds up the convergence. On the other hand, we can observe that as the number of devices goes to infinity, i.e., K→∞→𝐾K\rightarrow\infty, the impact of quantization diminish since the quantization errors average out thanks to the update aggregation mechanism. Moreover, We can obtain that Nϵ=⌈A+Dϵ−B−C⌉subscript𝑁italic-ϵ𝐴𝐷italic-ϵ𝐵𝐶N_{\epsilon}=\left\lceil\frac{A+D}{\epsilon}-B-C\right\rceil when q→∞→𝑞q\rightarrow\infty or K→∞→𝐾K\rightarrow\infty. In other words, ⌈A+Dϵ−B−C⌉𝐴𝐷italic-ϵ𝐵𝐶\left\lceil\frac{A+D}{\epsilon}-B-C\right\rceil can be used to evaluate the minimum communication rounds under high-resolution quantization or sufficient large number of devices, and this value offers us a lower bound of the minimum communication rounds under practical quantization levels and number of devices.

IV Training time minimization

In this section, we aim to jointly optimize the quantization level and the bandwidth allocation by minimizing the training time defined in (5) to achieve an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-optimality gap.

IV-A Problem formulation

The training time minimization problem is mathematically formulated by

(P1)​min q∈ℤ+,{bk},TdP1𝑞superscriptℤsubscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝑇𝑑min \displaystyle(\text{P1})\;\;\;\underset{q\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\{b_{k}\},T_{d}}{\text{min }}\;\;\; Td⋅Nϵ,⋅subscript𝑇𝑑subscript𝑁italic-ϵ\displaystyle T_{d}\cdot N_{\epsilon}, (17)
s.t. Tkcomp+Tkcomm≤Td,∀k∈[K],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\displaystyle T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}\leq T_{d},\;\forall k\in[K], (17a)
∑k=1Kbk=B0,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝐵0\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}=B_{0}, (17b)
q≥2,𝑞2\displaystyle q\geq 2, (17c)

where the objective function in (17) is the total training time needed to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-optimality gap. Constraints in (17a) indicate that the training time of each device per communication round cannot exceed the delay requirement Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d}. Equation (17b) constrains total bandwidth allocated to all the devices as B𝐵B. The constraint on the quantization level q𝑞q is described by (17c).

The objective function in (17) is complicated due to the coupling of the control variables Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d} and q𝑞q. Moreover, q𝑞q can only take values from positive integers. Therefore, Problem (P1) is non-convex, and challenging to be solved optimally. To yield a good solution to Problem (P1), we divide it into two sub-problems. One is finding the optimal bandwidth allocation {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d} with fixed quantization level q𝑞q; the other is finding the optimal quantization level q𝑞q with fixed bandwidth allocation {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d}. We will find that the first sub-problem can be solved optimally and efficiently with unique solution, and the second sub-problem can be transformed into a non-convex problem that can be solved by the method of successive convex approximation (SCA) [15]. Then, by alternatively solving each sub-problem, we can obtain good sub-optimal solutions to joint quantization level and bandwidth allocation optimization.

Remark 4 (Tradeoff between minimum communication rounds and per-round latency).

As noted in Remark 3, the minimum communication rounds Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} can be reduced by increasing the quantization levels q𝑞q, but at a cost of increased per-round latency. Therefore, there exists a fundamental trade-off between reducing the minimum communication rounds and suppressing the per-round latency when minimizing the total training time. The trade-off is manipulated by the setting of quantization level q𝑞q.

Remark 5 (Resource allocation over heterogeneous devices in FEEL).

The computation time of the devices varies due to their heterogeneous computation capacity. To enforce the per-round latency constraint, more frequency bandwidth should be allocated to the devices with low computation power so as to compensate the long computation time with short communication time, and vice versa. Hence, the bandwidth allocation among the devices should jointly account for the channel condition and also the computation resources, which is in sharp contrast to classic bandwidth allocation problem account for only the channel condition, e.g., in [36].

IV-B Bandwidth allocation optimization

Since Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} is independent with {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d}, Problem (17) under fixed quantization level q𝑞q reduces to

(P2)​min {bk},Td(P2)subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝑇𝑑min \displaystyle\text{(P2)}\;\;\;\underset{\{b_{k}\},T_{d}}{\text{min }}\;\;\; Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑\displaystyle T_{d} (18)

IV-C Quantization level optimization

Next, we focus on optimizing the quantization level q𝑞q under fixed bandwidth allocation. First, we relax the value of q𝑞q from integer to real number in interval q∈[2,+∞)𝑞2q\in[2,+\infty). For the convenience of optimization, we approximate Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} in Proposition 1 as Nϵ≈dq​K​H1+H2subscript𝑁italic-ϵ𝑑𝑞𝐾subscript𝐻1subscript𝐻2N_{\epsilon}\approx\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}H_{1}+H_{2}, where H1=Aϵ−Bsubscript𝐻1𝐴italic-ϵ𝐵H_{1}=\frac{A}{\epsilon}-B and H2=A+Dϵ−B−Csubscript𝐻2𝐴𝐷italic-ϵ𝐵𝐶H_{2}=\frac{A+D}{\epsilon}-B-C, by getting rid of the ceiling operation. s.t. (Tkcomp+Tkcomm)​(dq​K​H1+H2)≤T~,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘comm𝑑𝑞𝐾subscript𝐻1subscript𝐻2~𝑇\displaystyle\left(T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}H_{1}+H_{2}\right)\leq\tilde{T}, (22a)

The key idea is that in each iteration, the original problem is approximated by a tractable convex one at a given local point as elaborated below. Since the left side of constraint (24a) are jointly convex with respect to q𝑞q and T~~𝑇\tilde{T}, Problem (P3.1) is convex, which can be solved by standard convex optimization tools such as CVXPY [38]. After the iterations converge, e.g., the gap between T~(r)superscript~𝑇𝑟\tilde{T}^{(r)} and T~(r+1)superscript~𝑇𝑟1\tilde{T}^{(r+1)} is lower than a given threshold, Problem (P3) is deemed solved.

IV-D A joint optimization algorithm

Since the unique solution of Problem (P2) can be obtained by Algorithm 1 and a stationary point of Problem (P3) can be reached by Algorithm 2, the sub-optimal bandwidth allocation and quantization level can be jointly obtained by alternately solving Problem (P2) and (P3), which is summarized in Algorithm 3. It can be verified that the sub-optimal solution from Algorithm 3 is a stationary point of the original Problem (P1).

Note that solving Problem (P1) may lead to non-integer q𝑞q, which needs further rounding technique to yield an integer q𝑞q for practical implementation. One possible rounding technique is discussed as follows. We denote T​(q,{bk})𝑇𝑞subscript𝑏𝑘T(q,\{b_{k}\}) as the total training time in Problem (P1) when q𝑞q and {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} is substituted. After finding the optimized quantization level q^^𝑞\hat{q} and optimal bandwidth allocation {bk∗}superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘∗\{b_{k}^{\ast}\}, the final quantization level q∗superscript𝑞∗q^{\ast} is obtained as

q∗=arg⁡minq∈{⌈q^⌉−1,⌈q^⌉}⁡T​(q,{bk∗}).superscript𝑞∗subscript𝑞^𝑞1^𝑞𝑇𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘∗q^{\ast}=\arg\min_{q\in\{\lceil\hat{q}\rceil-1,\lceil\hat{q}\rceil\}}T(q,\{b_{k}^{\ast}\}).

V Experimental evaluation

In this section, we provide numerical results of two experiments under different wireless communication scenarios and learning tasks, which capture real system heterogeneity, to examine our theoretical results. In Experiment I, we consider a learning task with strongly convex loss function and training model of small size. In Experiment II, to stretch the theory, we consider a learning task with non-convex loss function and training model of large size. Although our analysis is developed based on the assumption of strongly convex loss function, we show that the proposed algorithm can also work well in the case with non-convex loss function. All experiments are implemented by PyTorch using Python 3.8 on a Linux server with one NVIDIA® GeForce® RTX 3090 GPU 24GB and one Intel® Xeon® Gold 5218 CPU.

V-A Experiment setup

FEEL system: We consider a FEEL system with a edge server covering a circular area of radius r=500𝑟500r=500 m. Within the area, K=6𝐾6K=6 edge devices are placed randomly and distributed uniformly over the circular area with the exclusion of a central disk of radius rh=100subscript𝑟ℎ100r_{h}=100 m. The transmit power of each device is 111 dBm. To expose the heterogeneity of the edge devices, the CPU frequency of each device is assumed to be uniformly distributed from 100100100 MHz to 1 GHz. The number of processing cycles of device k𝑘k for executing one batch of samples is ν=108𝜈superscript108\nu=10^{8} in Experiment I and ν=2.5×1010𝜈2.5superscript1010\nu=2.5\times 10^{10} in Experiment II.

Wireless propagation: The large-scale propagation coefficient in dB from device k𝑘k to the edge server is modeled as [ϕk]dB=[PLk]dB+[ζk]dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptPL𝑘dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑘dB[\phi_{k}]_{\text{dB}}=[\text{PL}_{k}]_{\text{dB}}+[\zeta_{k}]_{\text{dB}}, where [PLk]dB=128.1+37.6​log10⁡distksubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptPL𝑘dB128.137.6subscript10subscriptdist𝑘[\text{PL}_{k}]_{\text{dB}}=128.1+37.6\log_{10}\text{dist}_{k} (distksubscriptdist𝑘\text{dist}_{k} is the distance in kilometer) is the path loss in dB, and [ζk]dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑘dB[\zeta_{k}]_{\text{dB}} is the shadow fading in dB [39]. In this simulation, [ζk]dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑘dB[\zeta_{k}]_{\text{dB}} is Gauss-distributed random variable with mean zero and variance σζ2=8subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜁8\sigma^{2}_{\zeta}=8 dB. The noise power spectral density is N0=−174subscript𝑁0174N_{0}=-174 dBm/Hz, and the total bandwidth is B0=10subscript𝐵010B_{0}=10 KHz [28].

Learning tasks and models: In Experiment I, we consider the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} regularized logistic regression task on synthetic data [40]. The local loss function in (1) at device k𝑘k is given by

Fk​(𝐰)=1D​∑(𝐱i,yi)∈𝒟klog2⁡(1+exp⁡(−𝐱iT​𝐰​yi))+λ​‖𝐰‖22,subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰1𝐷subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘subscript21superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑇𝐰subscript𝑦𝑖𝜆superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐰22F_{k}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{D}\sum_{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\log_{2}\left(1+\exp(-\mathbf{x}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{w}y_{i})\right)+\lambda\|\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2},

where 𝐱i∈ℝdsubscript𝐱𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and yi∈{−1,1}subscript𝑦𝑖11y_{i}\in\{-1,1\}. The ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda is set to λ=10−6𝜆superscript106\lambda=10^{-6}. It can be verified that the local loss function Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is smooth and strongly convex. Each data sample (𝐱i,yi)subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i}) is generated in four steps as follows

  1. 1.

    Dense data generation: x¯i​j∼𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscript¯𝑥𝑖𝑗𝒩01\bar{x}_{ij}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1), ∀j∈[d]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑑\forall\;j\in[d];

    Label generation: 𝐰∼𝒩​(0,𝐈d)similar-to𝐰𝒩0subscript𝐈𝑑\mathbf{w}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}_{d}), yi←sgn​(𝐱¯iT​𝐰)←subscript𝑦𝑖sgnsuperscriptsubscript¯𝐱𝑖𝑇𝐰y_{i}\leftarrow\mathrm{sgn}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{w}).

Note that the parameters Δ1subscriptΔ1\Delta_{1} and Δ2subscriptΔ2\Delta_{2} control the sparsity of data points and the gradients333From our experiments, the effect of stochastic quantization on SGD convergence depends heavily on the sparsity structure of the gradients. Therefore, we choose this dataset in Experiment I to better validate our theoretical results. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, how the sparsity structure of the gradients affects the learning algorithm that employs stochastic quantization as compression scheme has not been revealed in the literature, which is an interesting topic but beyond the scope of this work. [40]. The parameters Δ1subscriptΔ1\Delta_{1} and Δ2subscriptΔ2\Delta_{2} are set to 0.90.90.9 and 0.250.250.25 in this experiment. Moreover, the dimension of each data point is set to d=1024𝑑1024d=1024. Hence, the model contains 1024 parameters in total. We generate 48,000 data points for training and 12,000 data points for validation.

In Experiment II, we consider the learning task of image classification using the well-known CIFAR-10 dataset, which consists of 50,000 training images and 10,000 validation images in 10 categories of colorful objectives such as airplanes, cars, etc. ResNet-20 (269,722 parameters in total) with batch normalization444The implementation of ResNet-20 follows this GitHub repository: https://github.com/hclhkbu/GaussianK-SGD [41]. is applied as the classifier model [42].

Training and optimization parameters: We consider a decaying learning rate as ηn=5n+10subscript𝜂𝑛5𝑛10\eta_{n}=\frac{5}{n+10} in Experiment I, where n𝑛n is the index of communication round, and the learning rate is set to ηn=100n+1000subscript𝜂𝑛100𝑛1000\eta_{n}=\frac{100}{n+1000} in Experiment II. To deliver rigorous results, we strictly control all unrelated variables in both experiments.

V-B Experiment results in Experiment I

V-B1 Estimation of data-related parameters

In the optimization in Section IV-C, we need to obtain the values of H1subscript𝐻1H_{1} and H2subscript𝐻2H_{2} using the proposed joint data-and-model-driven fitting method in Section III-C. With the joint data-and-model-driven fitting method, for any given two quantization levels q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}, and the threshold of loss optimality gap upper bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, we can obtain an estimation of H1subscript𝐻1H_{1} and H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}, which are used in Algorithm 3. Also, the optimal loss value can be obtained by the estimation of Z𝑍Z in Eq. (9), i.e., F​(𝐰∗)≈Z≈0.247𝐹subscript𝐰∗𝑍0.247F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})\approx Z\approx 0.247. The threshold of loss optimality gap upper bound is set as ϵ=0.012italic-ϵ0.012\epsilon=0.012. One can choose any combination of q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2} to implement the estimation in theory. As a reminder to the readers, however, in our experience, the combination of q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2} with large difference leads to better estimation accuracy. In our results, we choose (q1,q2)=(4,6)subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞246(q_{1},q_{2})=(4,6) in the joint data-and-model-driven fitting method, and obtain that H1≈43.01subscript𝐻143.01H_{1}\approx 43.01 and H2≈48.79subscript𝐻248.79H_{2}\approx 48.79. To show the robustness of our estimation method, we plot the fitted loss function and the actual loss when the quantization levels are q1=4subscript𝑞14q_{1}=4 and q2=6subscript𝑞26q_{2}=6, and also other values than q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}, e.g., 888 and 161616, as shown in Fig. 3, and we can see that the fitted loss function fits the actual loss well.

V-B2 Optimization of quantization level

Fig. 4 plots the total training time versus communication round in simulation when the bandwidth allocation is optimal. We run the same training process for at least 5 times on each quantization level. Fig. 4 shows that there exists optimal quantization level that minimizes the total training time. Recall the facts from Section III that the total training time T=Nϵ⋅Td𝑇⋅subscript𝑁italic-ϵsubscript𝑇𝑑T=N_{\epsilon}\cdot T_{d}, and Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} is an decreasing function of quantization level q𝑞q, while Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d} is an increasing function of q𝑞q. In other words, Fig. 4 demonstrates the trade-off between total communication rounds Nϵsubscript𝑁italic-ϵN_{\epsilon} and per-round latency Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d} in FEEL system. Moreover, it can be observed from the figure that the optimal quantization levels obtained in theory from Algorithm 3 in Section IV match the results by simulation, which confirms the validity of our proposed algorithms. In Fig. 5(a), we compare the training loss under optimal quantization level and optimal bandwidth allocation and the training loss under other quantization level and optimal bandwidth allocation. It can be observed that the training loss of optimal quantization level under optimal bandwidth allocation reaches the predefined threshold in a shorter time.

V-B3 Optimization of bandwidth

Fig. 5 depicts the comparison between the schemes with optimal and equal bandwidth allocation in terms of loss optimality gap and test accuracy. We can observe that the scheme with optimal bandwidth allocation can reach the predefined threshold and obtain a higher test accuracy in a shorter time. This indicates that our bandwidth allocation algorithm is effective and necessary in FEEL system. To show how the heterogeneous computation power of edge devices affect the communication resource allocation, we present the CPU frequency of each edge device and its corresponding optimal allocated bandwidth in Fig. 6. It can be observed that the edge devices with lower CPU frequency will be allocated with a larger bandwidth, which in spirit has similarity to the well-known phenomenon of “water-filling” in the problem of power allocation in wireless communication [36].

V-C Experiment results in Experiment II

We conduct Experiment II to evaluate our method and algorithms on learning model with non-convex loss function. In this experiment, we choose (q1,q2)=(15,20)subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞21520(q_{1},q_{2})=(15,20) and obtain H1≈96.26subscript𝐻196.26H_{1}\approx 96.26 and H2≈808.53subscript𝐻2808.53H_{2}\approx 808.53 by our joint data-and-model-driven fitting method. The threshold of loss optimality gap upper bound is set as ϵ=0.22italic-ϵ0.22\epsilon=0.22. Fig. 7 shows the total training time versus quantization level in simulation when the bandwidth allocation is optimal; Fig. 8 shows the loss value and test accuracy versus training time in simulation with different quantization levels and bandwidth allocations. We can obtain the similar observations from Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 as in Experiment I, which reveals that our method and algorithm also work well in non-convex setting, although they are derived under strongly-convex setting.

VI Conclusion

This paper have studied the training time minimization for quantized FEEL with optimized quantization level and bandwidth allocation. On the basis of the convergence analysis of quantized FEEL and our proposed joint-data-and-model-driven fitting method, we derived the closed-form expression of the total training time and characterizes the trade-off between the convergence speed and communication overhead, which is governed by the quantization level. Next, we minimized the total training time by optimizing the quantization level and bandwidth allocation, for which a high-quality near-optimal solutions are obtained by alternating optimization. The theoretical results developed can be used to guide the system optimization and contribute to the understanding of how wireless communication system can properly coordinate resources to accomplish learning tasks. This also opens several directions for further research. One direction is to implement device sampling in quantized FEEL, in which how the bandwidth is allocated to minimize the training time is completely a different story. The other direction is to consider error compensation in quantized FEEL to mitigate the effects of compression errors.

B-A Bound of ‖𝐚1‖2superscriptnormsubscript𝐚12\left\|\mathbf{a}_{1}\right\|^{2}

To bound B1subscript𝐵1B_{1}, we use ‖∑k=1K𝐚k‖2≤K​∑k=1K‖𝐚k‖2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐚𝑘2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptnormsubscript𝐚𝑘2\|\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{a}_{k}\|^{2}\leq K\sum_{k=1}^{K}\|\mathbf{a}_{k}\|^{2}. This gives

B1≤ηn2K​∑k=1K‖𝐠k(n)‖2.subscript𝐵1superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑛2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle B_{1}\leq\frac{\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\|^{2}.

By the μ𝜇\mu-strongly convexity of Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), it follows that

⟨𝐰∗−𝐰(n),𝐠k(n)⟩subscript𝐰∗superscript𝐰𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\left\langle\mathbf{w}_{\ast}-\mathbf{w}^{(n)},\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\rangle
≤\displaystyle\leq Fk​(𝐰∗)−Fk​(𝐰(n))−μ2​‖𝐰(n)−𝐰∗‖2.subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛𝜇2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})-\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}.

B-B Bound of ‖𝐚2‖2subscriptnormsubscript𝐚22\left\|\mathbf{a}_{2}\right\|_{2}

Since 𝐠k(n)superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}’s are independent and 𝔼𝒬​[‖𝒬​(𝐠k(n))−𝐠k(n)‖]2≤dq​‖𝐠k(n)‖2subscript𝔼𝒬superscriptdelimited-[]norm𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛2𝑑𝑞superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛2\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)})-\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\|\right]^{2}\leq\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q}\left\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\|^{2} holds, it follows that

𝔼𝒬​[‖𝐚2‖2]≤d​ηn2q​K2​∑k=1K‖𝐠k(n)‖2.subscript𝔼𝒬delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝐚22𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑛2𝑞superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛2\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{Q}}[\left\|\mathbf{a}_{2}\right\|^{2}]\leq\frac{\sqrt{d}\eta_{n}^{2}}{qK^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\|^{2}.

B-C Bound of (25)

With these bounds at hand, taking expectation of (25) over the stochastic quantizer 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} and stochastic gradient at round n𝑛n, we have that

𝔼​[‖𝐰(n+1)−𝐰∗‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛1subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
≤(1−μ​ηn)​‖𝐰(n)−𝐰∗‖2absent1𝜇subscript𝜂𝑛superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}
+2​ηnK​∑k=1K(Fk​(𝐰∗)−Fk​(𝐰(n)))2subscript𝜂𝑛𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle+2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)
+α​ηn2K​∑k=1K𝔼​‖𝐠k(n)‖2.𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑛2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\|^{2}. (26)

Recall that α=dq​K+1𝛼𝑑𝑞𝐾1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1. From Assumption 3, we have that

𝔼​‖𝐠k(n)‖2≤δk2+‖∇Fk​(𝐰(n))‖2.𝔼superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛2\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\|^{2}\leq\delta_{k}^{2}+\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}. (27)

After substituting (27) into (26), it yields

𝔼​[‖𝐰(n+1)−𝐰∗‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛1subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
≤(1−μ​ηn)​‖𝐰(n)−𝐰∗‖2absent1𝜇subscript𝜂𝑛superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}
+2​ηnK​∑k=1K(Fk​(𝐰∗)−Fk​(𝐰(n)))2subscript𝜂𝑛𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle+2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)
+α​ηn2K​∑k=1K(δk2+‖∇Fk​(𝐰(n))‖2).𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑛2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛2\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\delta_{k}^{2}+\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}\right).

The L𝐿L-smoothness of Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) gives that

‖∇Fk​(𝐰(n))‖2≤2​L​(Fk​(𝐰(n))−Fk∗),superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛22𝐿subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘∗\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}\leq 2L\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})-F_{k}^{\ast}\right),

It follows that

𝔼​[‖𝐰(n+1)−𝐰∗‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛1subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
≤(1−μ​ηn)​‖𝐰(n)−𝐰∗‖2+α​ηn2K​∑k=1Kδk2absent1𝜇subscript𝜂𝑛superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰∗2𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑛2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}+\frac{\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\delta_{k}^{2}
+2​ηnK​∑k=1K(Fk​(𝐰∗)−Fk​(𝐰(n)))⏟C1subscript⏟2subscript𝜂𝑛𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰∗subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐶1\displaystyle+\underbrace{2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)}_{C_{1}}

𝔼​[‖𝐰(n+1)−𝐰∗‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛1subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right] ≤(1−μ​ηn)​𝔼​[‖𝐰(n)−𝐰∗‖2]absent1𝜇subscript𝜂𝑛𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰∗2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 1

If Tkcomp+Tkcomm<Tdsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}<T_{d}, ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K], Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d} can be reduced until some k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] satisfy that Tkcomp+Tkcomm=Tdsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=T_{d}. Denote 𝒦={k∈[K]|Tkcomp+Tkcomm<Td}𝒦conditional-set𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑\mathcal{K}=\{k\in[K]|T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}<T_{d}\} and 𝒦¯={k∈[K]|Tkcomp+Tkcomm=Td}¯𝒦conditional-set𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑\bar{\mathcal{K}}=\{k\in[K]|T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=T_{d}\}. Obviously, 𝒦+𝒦¯=[K]𝒦¯𝒦delimited-[]𝐾\mathcal{K}+\bar{\mathcal{K}}=[K]. Since Tkcommsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commT_{k}^{\text{comm}} is an decreasing function of bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}, we can enforce Tkcomp+Tkcomm=Tdsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=T_{d} by decreasing bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} for all k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. Then, 𝒦=∅𝒦\mathcal{K}=\emptyset and 𝒦¯=[K]¯𝒦delimited-[]𝐾\bar{\mathcal{K}}=[K]. In this case, if ∑k=1Kbk<Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑏𝑘𝐵\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}<B, we can properly increase each bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}, without violating Tkcomp+Tkcomm=Tdsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘commsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=T_{d}, k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], until ∑k=1Kbk=Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑏𝑘𝐵\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}=B, and Tdsubscript𝑇𝑑T_{d} will decrease as well.
